quad

  • quad(x1, y1, x2, y2, x3, y3, x4, y4, detailX?, detailY?): p5

  • Draws a quad to the canvas. A quad is a quadrilateral, a four-sided polygon. Some examples of quads include rectangles, squares, rhombuses, and trapezoids. The first pair of parameters (x1,y1) sets the quad's first point. The following pairs of parameters set the coordinates for its next three points. Parameters should proceed clockwise or counter-clockwise around the shape. The version of quad() with twelve parameters allows the quad to be drawn in 3D space. Doing so requires adding the WEBGL argument to createCanvas().

    Parameters

    • x1: number

      the x-coordinate of the first point.

    • y1: number

      the y-coordinate of the first point.

    • x2: number

      the x-coordinate of the second point.

    • y2: number

      the y-coordinate of the second point.

    • x3: number

      the x-coordinate of the third point.

    • y3: number

      the y-coordinate of the third point.

    • x4: number

      the x-coordinate of the fourth point.

    • y4: number

      the y-coordinate of the fourth point.

    • Optional detailX: number

      number of segments in the x-direction.

    • Optional detailY: number

      number of segments in the y-direction.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.quad

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/2d_primitives.d.ts:217
  • quad(x1, y1, z1, x2, y2, z2, x3, y3, z3, x4, y4, z4, detailX?, detailY?): p5

  • Draws a quad to the canvas. A quad is a quadrilateral, a four-sided polygon. Some examples of quads include rectangles, squares, rhombuses, and trapezoids. The first pair of parameters (x1,y1) sets the quad's first point. The following pairs of parameters set the coordinates for its next three points. Parameters should proceed clockwise or counter-clockwise around the shape. The version of quad() with twelve parameters allows the quad to be drawn in 3D space. Doing so requires adding the WEBGL argument to createCanvas().

    Parameters

    • x1: number

      the x-coordinate of the first point.

    • y1: number

      the y-coordinate of the first point.

    • z1: number

      the z-coordinate of the first point.

    • x2: number

      the x-coordinate of the second point.

    • y2: number

      the y-coordinate of the second point.

    • z2: number

      the z-coordinate of the second point.

    • x3: number

      the x-coordinate of the third point.

    • y3: number

      the y-coordinate of the third point.

    • z3: number

      the z-coordinate of the third point.

    • x4: number

      the x-coordinate of the fourth point.

    • y4: number

      the y-coordinate of the fourth point.

    • z4: number

      the z-coordinate of the fourth point.

    • Optional detailX: number

      number of segments in the x-direction.

    • Optional detailY: number

      number of segments in the y-direction.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.quad

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/2d_primitives.d.ts:261

quadraticVertex

  • quadraticVertex(cx, cy, x3, y3): p5

  • Specifies vertex coordinates for quadratic Bezier curves. Each call to quadraticVertex() defines the position of one control points and one anchor point of a Bezier curve, adding a new segment to a line or shape. The first time quadraticVertex() is used within a beginShape() call, it must be prefaced with a call to vertex() to set the first anchor point. For WebGL mode quadraticVertex() can be used in 2D as well as 3D mode. 2D mode expects 4 parameters, while 3D mode expects 6 parameters (including z coordinates). This function must be used between beginShape() and endShape() and only when there is no MODE or POINTS parameter specified to beginShape().

    Parameters

    • cx: number

      x-coordinate for the control point

    • cy: number

      y-coordinate for the control point

    • x3: number

      x-coordinate for the anchor point

    • y3: number

      y-coordinate for the anchor point

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.quadraticVertex

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/vertex.d.ts:248
  • quadraticVertex(cx, cy, cz, x3, y3, z3): p5

  • Specifies vertex coordinates for quadratic Bezier curves. Each call to quadraticVertex() defines the position of one control points and one anchor point of a Bezier curve, adding a new segment to a line or shape. The first time quadraticVertex() is used within a beginShape() call, it must be prefaced with a call to vertex() to set the first anchor point. For WebGL mode quadraticVertex() can be used in 2D as well as 3D mode. 2D mode expects 4 parameters, while 3D mode expects 6 parameters (including z coordinates). This function must be used between beginShape() and endShape() and only when there is no MODE or POINTS parameter specified to beginShape().

    Parameters

    • cx: number

      x-coordinate for the control point

    • cy: number

      y-coordinate for the control point

    • cz: number

      z-coordinate for the control point (for WebGL mode)

    • x3: number

      x-coordinate for the anchor point

    • y3: number

      y-coordinate for the anchor point

    • z3: number

      z-coordinate for the anchor point (for WebGL mode)

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.quadraticVertex

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/vertex.d.ts:275

radians

  • radians(degrees): number

  • Converts a degree measurement to its corresponding value in radians. Radians and degrees are two ways of measuring the same thing. There are 360 degrees in a circle and 2*PI radians in a circle. For example, 90 = PI/2 = 1.5707964. This function does not take into account the current angleMode.

    Parameters

    • degrees: number

      the degree value to convert to radians

    Returns number

    the converted angle

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.radians

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/trigonometry.d.ts:114

random

  • random(min?, max?): number

  • Return a random floating-point number. Takes either 0, 1 or 2 arguments.

    If no argument is given, returns a random number from 0 up to (but not including) 1.

    If one argument is given and it is a number, returns a random number from 0 up to (but not including) the number.

    If one argument is given and it is an array, returns a random element from that array.

    If two arguments are given, returns a random number from the first argument up to (but not including) the second argument.

    Parameters

    • Optional min: number

      the lower bound (inclusive)

    • Optional max: number

      the upper bound (exclusive)

    Returns number

    the random number

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.random

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/random.d.ts:38
  • random(choices): any

  • Return a random floating-point number. Takes either 0, 1 or 2 arguments.

    If no argument is given, returns a random number from 0 up to (but not including) 1.

    If one argument is given and it is a number, returns a random number from 0 up to (but not including) the number.

    If one argument is given and it is an array, returns a random element from that array.

    If two arguments are given, returns a random number from the first argument up to (but not including) the second argument.

    Parameters

    • choices: any[]

      the array to choose from

    Returns any

    the random element from the array

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.random

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/random.d.ts:60

randomGaussian

  • randomGaussian(mean?, sd?): number

  • Returns a random number fitting a Gaussian, or normal, distribution. There is theoretically no minimum or maximum value that randomGaussian() might return. Rather, there is just a very low probability that values far from the mean will be returned; and a higher probability that numbers near the mean will be returned. Takes either 0, 1 or 2 arguments. If no args, the mean is 0 and the standard deviation is 1.

    If one arg, that arg is the mean and the standard deviation is 1.

    If two args, the first arg is the mean and the second is the standard deviation.

    Parameters

    • Optional mean: number

      the mean

    • Optional sd: number

      the standard deviation

    Returns number

    the random number

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.randomGaussian

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/random.d.ts:82

randomSeed

  • randomSeed(seed): void

  • Sets the seed value for random(). By default, random() produces different results each time the program is run. Set the seed parameter to a constant to return the same pseudo-random numbers each time the software is run.

    Parameters

    • seed: number

      the seed value

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.randomSeed

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/random.d.ts:15

rect

  • rect(x, y, w, h?, tl?, tr?, br?, bl?): p5

  • Draws a rectangle to the canvas. A rectangle is a four-sided polygon with every angle at ninety degrees. By default, the first two parameters set the location of the rectangle's upper-left corner. The third and fourth set the shape's the width and height, respectively. The way these parameters are interpreted may be changed with the rectMode() function. The version of rect() with five parameters creates a rounded rectangle. The fifth parameter is used as the radius value for all four corners.

    The version of rect() with eight parameters also creates a rounded rectangle. When using eight parameters, the latter four set the radius of the arc at each corner separately. The radii start with the top-left corner and move clockwise around the rectangle. If any of these parameters are omitted, they are set to the value of the last specified corner radius.

    Parameters

    • x: number

      x-coordinate of the rectangle.

    • y: number

      y-coordinate of the rectangle.

    • w: number

      width of the rectangle.

    • Optional h: number

      height of the rectangle.

    • Optional tl: number

      optional radius of top-left corner.

    • Optional tr: number

      optional radius of top-right corner.

    • Optional br: number

      optional radius of bottom-right corner.

    • Optional bl: number

      optional radius of bottom-left corner.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.rect

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/2d_primitives.d.ts:310
  • rect(x, y, w, h, detailX?, detailY?): p5

  • Draws a rectangle to the canvas. A rectangle is a four-sided polygon with every angle at ninety degrees. By default, the first two parameters set the location of the rectangle's upper-left corner. The third and fourth set the shape's the width and height, respectively. The way these parameters are interpreted may be changed with the rectMode() function. The version of rect() with five parameters creates a rounded rectangle. The fifth parameter is used as the radius value for all four corners.

    The version of rect() with eight parameters also creates a rounded rectangle. When using eight parameters, the latter four set the radius of the arc at each corner separately. The radii start with the top-left corner and move clockwise around the rectangle. If any of these parameters are omitted, they are set to the value of the last specified corner radius.

    Parameters

    • x: number

      x-coordinate of the rectangle.

    • y: number

      y-coordinate of the rectangle.

    • w: number

      width of the rectangle.

    • h: number

      height of the rectangle.

    • Optional detailX: number

      number of segments in the x-direction (for WebGL mode).

    • Optional detailY: number

      number of segments in the y-direction (for WebGL mode).

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.rect

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/2d_primitives.d.ts:343

rectMode

  • rectMode(mode): p5

  • Modifies the location from which rectangles and squares are drawn. By default, the first two parameters are the x- and y-coordinates of the shape's upper-left corner. The next parameters are its width and height. This is equivalent to calling rectMode(CORNER). rectMode(CORNERS) also uses the first two parameters as the location of one of the corners. The third and fourth parameters are the location of the opposite corner.

    rectMode(CENTER) uses the first two parameters as the x- and y-coordinates of the shape's center. The next parameters are its width and height.

    rectMode(RADIUS) also uses the first two parameters as the x- and y-coordinates of the shape's center. The next parameters are half of the shape's width and height.

    The argument passed to rectMode() must be written in ALL CAPS because the constants CENTER, RADIUS, CORNER, and CORNERS are defined this way. JavaScript is a case-sensitive language.

    Parameters

    • mode: RECT_MODE

      either CORNER, CORNERS, CENTER, or RADIUS

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.rectMode

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/attributes.d.ts:81

red

  • red(color): number

  • Extracts the red value from a p5.Color object, array of color components, or CSS color string.

    Parameters

    • color: string | number[] | p5.Color

      p5.Color object, array of color components, or CSS color string.

    Returns number

    the red value.

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.red

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/color/creating_reading.d.ts:252

redraw

  • redraw(n?): void

  • Executes the code within draw() one time. This function allows the program to update the display window only when necessary, for example when an event registered by mousePressed() or keyPressed() occurs. In structuring a program, it only makes sense to call redraw() within events such as mousePressed(). This is because redraw() does not run draw() immediately (it only sets a flag that indicates an update is needed).

    The redraw() function does not work properly when called inside draw().To enable/disable animations, use loop() and noLoop().

    In addition you can set the number of redraws per method call. Just add an integer as single parameter for the number of redraws.

    Parameters

    • Optional n: number

      Redraw for n-times. The default value is 1.

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.redraw

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/structure.d.ts:137

remove

  • remove(): void

  • Removes the entire p5 sketch. This will remove the canvas and any elements created by p5.js. It will also stop the draw loop and unbind any properties or methods from the window global scope. It will leave a variable p5 in case you wanted to create a new p5 sketch. If you like, you can set p5 = null to erase it. While all functions and variables and objects created by the p5 library will be removed, any other global variables created by your code will remain.

    Returns void

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/index.d.ts:167

removeElements

  • removeElements(): void

  • Removes all elements created by p5, except any canvas / graphics elements created by createCanvas or createGraphics. Event handlers are removed, and element is removed from the DOM.

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.removeElements

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/dom/dom.d.ts:298

removeItem

  • removeItem(key): void

  • Removes an item that was stored with storeItem()

    Parameters

    • key: string

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.removeItem

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/data/local_storage.d.ts:37

requestPointerLock

  • requestPointerLock(): void

  • The function requestPointerLock() locks the pointer to its current position and makes it invisible. Use movedX and movedY to get the difference the mouse was moved since the last call of draw. Note that not all browsers support this feature. This enables you to create experiences that aren't limited by the mouse moving out of the screen even if it is repeatedly moved into one direction. For example, a first person perspective experience.

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.requestPointerLock

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/events/mouse.d.ts:136

resetMatrix

  • resetMatrix(): p5

  • Replaces the current matrix with the identity matrix.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.resetMatrix

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:117

resetShader

  • resetShader(): p5

  • Restores the default shaders. Code that runs after resetShader() will not be affected by the shader previously set by shader()

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.resetShader

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/material.d.ts:66

resizeCanvas

  • resizeCanvas(w, h, noRedraw?): void

  • Resizes the canvas to given width and height. The canvas will be cleared and draw will be called immediately, allowing the sketch to re-render itself in the resized canvas.

    Parameters

    • w: number

      width of the canvas

    • h: number

      height of the canvas

    • Optional noRedraw: boolean

      don't redraw the canvas immediately

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.resizeCanvas

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/rendering.d.ts:100

reverse

  • reverse(list): any[]

  • Reverses the order of an array, maps to Array.reverse()

    Parameters

    • list: any[]

      Array to reverse

    Returns any[]

    the reversed list

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.reverse

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/utilities/array_functions.d.ts:85

rotate

  • rotate(angle, axis?): p5

  • Rotates a shape by the amount specified by the angle parameter. This function accounts for angleMode, so angles can be entered in either RADIANS or DEGREES. Objects are always rotated around their relative position to the origin and positive numbers rotate objects in a clockwise direction. Transformations apply to everything that happens after and subsequent calls to the function accumulate the effect. For example, calling rotate(HALF_PI) and then rotate(HALF_PI) is the same as rotate(PI). All transformations are reset when draw() begins again.

    Technically, rotate() multiplies the current transformation matrix by a rotation matrix. This function can be further controlled by push() and pop().

    Parameters

    • angle: number

      the angle of rotation, specified in radians or degrees, depending on current angleMode

    • Optional axis: number[] | Vector

      (in 3d) the axis to rotate around

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.rotate

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:142

rotateX

  • rotateX(angle): p5

  • Rotates a shape around X axis by the amount specified in angle parameter. The angles can be entered in either RADIANS or DEGREES. Objects are always rotated around their relative position to the origin and positive numbers rotate objects in a clockwise direction. All transformations are reset when draw() begins again.

    Parameters

    • angle: number

      the angle of rotation, specified in radians or degrees, depending on current angleMode

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.rotateX

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:156

rotateY

  • rotateY(angle): p5

  • Rotates a shape around Y axis by the amount specified in angle parameter. The angles can be entered in either RADIANS or DEGREES. Objects are always rotated around their relative position to the origin and positive numbers rotate objects in a clockwise direction. All transformations are reset when draw() begins again.

    Parameters

    • angle: number

      the angle of rotation, specified in radians or degrees, depending on current angleMode

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.rotateY

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:170

rotateZ

  • rotateZ(angle): p5

  • Rotates a shape around Z axis by the amount specified in angle parameter. The angles can be entered in either RADIANS or DEGREES. This method works in WEBGL mode only.

    Objects are always rotated around their relative position to the origin and positive numbers rotate objects in a clockwise direction. All transformations are reset when draw() begins again.

    Parameters

    • angle: number

      the angle of rotation, specified in radians or degrees, depending on current angleMode

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.rotateZ

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:187

round

  • round(n, decimals?): number

  • Calculates the integer closest to the n parameter. For example, round(133.8) returns the value 134. Maps to Math.round().

    Parameters

    • n: number

      number to round

    • Optional decimals: number

      number of decimal places to round to, default is 0

    Returns number

    rounded number

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.round

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/calculation.d.ts:229

saturation

  • saturation(color): number

  • Extracts the saturation value from a p5.Color object, array of color components, or CSS color string. Saturation is scaled differently in HSB and HSL. By default, this function returns the HSL saturation. If the colorMode() is set to HSB, it returns the HSB saturation.

    Parameters

    • color: string | number[] | p5.Color

      p5.Color object, array of color components, or CSS color string.

    Returns number

    the saturation value

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.saturation

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/color/creating_reading.d.ts:265

save

  • save(objectOrFilename?, filename?, options?): void

  • Saves a given element(image, text, json, csv, wav, or html) to the client's computer. The first parameter can be a pointer to element we want to save. The element can be one of p5.Element,an Array of Strings, an Array of JSON, a JSON object, a p5.Table , a p5.Image, or a p5.SoundFile (requires p5.sound). The second parameter is a filename (including extension).The third parameter is for options specific to this type of object. This method will save a file that fits the given parameters. If it is called without specifying an element, by default it will save the whole canvas as an image file. You can optionally specify a filename as the first parameter in such a case. Note that it is not recommended to call this method within draw, as it will open a new save dialog on every render.

    Parameters

    • Optional objectOrFilename: string | object

      If filename is provided, will save canvas as an image with either png or jpg extension depending on the filename. If object is provided, will save depending on the object and filename (see examples above).

    • Optional filename: string

      If an object is provided as the first parameter, then the second parameter indicates the filename, and should include an appropriate file extension (see examples above).

    • Optional options: string | boolean

      Additional options depend on filetype. For example, when saving JSON, true indicates that the output will be optimized for filesize, rather than readability.

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.save

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/io/files.d.ts:484

saveCanvas

  • saveCanvas(selectedCanvas, filename?, extension?): void

  • Save the current canvas as an image. The browser will either save the file immediately, or prompt the user with a dialogue window.

    Parameters

    • selectedCanvas: HTMLCanvasElement | Element

      a variable representing a specific html5 canvas (optional)

    • Optional filename: string
    • Optional extension: string

      'jpg' or 'png'

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.saveCanvas

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/image/image.d.ts:41
  • saveCanvas(filename?, extension?): void

  • Save the current canvas as an image. The browser will either save the file immediately, or prompt the user with a dialogue window.

    Parameters

    • Optional filename: string
    • Optional extension: string

      'jpg' or 'png'

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.saveCanvas

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/image/image.d.ts:49

saveFrames

  • saveFrames(filename, extension, duration, framerate, callback?): void

  • Capture a sequence of frames that can be used to create a movie. Accepts a callback. For example, you may wish to send the frames to a server where they can be stored or converted into a movie. If no callback is provided, the browser will pop up save dialogues in an attempt to download all of the images that have just been created. With the callback provided the image data isn't saved by default but instead passed as an argument to the callback function as an array of objects, with the size of array equal to the total number of frames. The arguments duration and framerate are constrained to be less or equal to 15 and 22, respectively, which means you can only download a maximum of 15 seconds worth of frames at 22 frames per second, adding up to 330 frames. This is done in order to avoid memory problems since a large enough canvas can fill up the memory in your computer very easily and crash your program or even your browser.

    To export longer animations, you might look into a library like ccapture.js.

    Parameters

    • filename: string
    • extension: string

      'jpg' or 'png'

    • duration: number

      Duration in seconds to save the frames for. This parameter will be constrained to be less or equal to 15.

    • framerate: number

      Framerate to save the frames in. This parameter will be constrained to be less or equal to 22.

    • Optional callback: ((p1) => any)

      A callback function that will be executed to handle the image data. This function should accept an array as argument. The array will contain the specified number of frames of objects. Each object has three properties: imageData - an image/octet-stream, filename and extension.

        • (p1): any

        • Parameters

          • p1: any[]

          Returns any

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.saveFrames

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/image/image.d.ts:89

saveGif

  • saveGif(filename, duration, options): void

  • Generates a gif of your current animation and downloads it to your computer! The duration argument specifies how many seconds you want to record from your animation. This value is then converted to the necessary number of frames to generate it, depending on the value of units. More on that on the next paragraph.

    An optional object that can contain two more arguments: delay (number) and units (string).

    delay, specifying how much time we should wait before recording

    units, a string that can be either 'seconds' or 'frames'. By default it's 'seconds'.

    units specifies how the duration and delay arguments will behave. If 'seconds', these arguments will correspond to seconds, meaning that 3 seconds worth of animation will be created. If 'frames', the arguments now correspond to the number of frames you want your animation to be, if you are very sure of this number.

    This may be called in setup, or, like in the example below, inside an event function, like keyPressed or mousePressed.

    Parameters

    • filename: string

      File name of your gif

    • duration: number

      Duration in seconds that you wish to capture from your sketch

    • options: object

      An optional object that can contain five more arguments: delay, specifying how much time we should wait before recording; units, a string that can be either 'seconds' or 'frames'. By default it's 'seconds; silent, a boolean that defines presence of progress notifications. By default its false; notificationDuration, a number that defines how long in seconds the final notification will live. 0, the default value, means that the notification will never be removed; notificationID, a string that specifies the notification DOM element id. By default its 'progressBar.

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.saveGif

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/image/loading_displaying.d.ts:81

saveJSON

  • saveJSON(json, filename, optimize?): void

  • Writes the contents of an Array or a JSON object to a .json file. The file saving process and location of the saved file will vary between web browsers.

    Parameters

    • json: object | any[]
    • filename: string
    • Optional optimize: boolean

      If true, removes line breaks and spaces from the output file to optimize filesize (but not readability).

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.saveJSON

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/io/files.d.ts:495

    • filename: string

    • Optional extension: string

    • Optional isCRLF: boolean

      if true, change line-break to CRLF

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.saveStrings

saveTable

  • saveTable(Table, filename, options?): void

  • Writes the contents of a Table object to a file. Defaults to a text file with comma-separated-values ('csv') but can also use tab separation ('tsv'), or generate an HTML table ('html'). The file saving process and location of the saved file will vary between web browsers.

    Parameters

    • Table: Table

      the Table object to save to a file

    • filename: string

      the filename to which the Table should be saved

    • Optional options: string

      can be one of "tsv", "csv", or "html"

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.saveTable

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/io/files.d.ts:522

scale

  • scale(s, y?, z?): p5

  • Increases or decreases the size of a shape by expanding or contracting vertices. Objects always scale from their relative origin to the coordinate system. Scale values are specified as decimal percentages. For example, the function call scale(2.0) increases the dimension of a shape by 200%. Transformations apply to everything that happens after and subsequent calls to the function multiply the effect. For example, calling scale(2.0) and then scale(1.5) is the same as scale(3.0). If scale() is called within draw(), the transformation is reset when the loop begins again.

    Using this function with the z parameter is only available in WEBGL mode. This function can be further controlled with push() and pop().

    Parameters

    • s: number | number[] | Vector

      percent to scale the object, or percentage to scale the object in the x-axis if multiple arguments are given

    • Optional y: number

      percent to scale the object in the y-axis

    • Optional z: number

      percent to scale the object in the z-axis (webgl only)

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.scale

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:216
  • scale(scales): p5

  • Increases or decreases the size of a shape by expanding or contracting vertices. Objects always scale from their relative origin to the coordinate system. Scale values are specified as decimal percentages. For example, the function call scale(2.0) increases the dimension of a shape by 200%. Transformations apply to everything that happens after and subsequent calls to the function multiply the effect. For example, calling scale(2.0) and then scale(1.5) is the same as scale(3.0). If scale() is called within draw(), the transformation is reset when the loop begins again.

    Using this function with the z parameter is only available in WEBGL mode. This function can be further controlled with push() and pop().

    Parameters

    • scales: number[] | Vector

      per-axis percents to scale the object

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.scale

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:240

    Returns number

select

  • select(selectors, container?): Element

  • Searches the page for the first element that matches the given CSS selector string (can be an ID, class, tag name or a combination) and returns it as a p5.Element. The DOM node itself can be accessed with .elt. Returns null if none found. You can also specify a container to search within.

    Parameters

    • selectors: string

      CSS selector string of element to search for

    • Optional container: string | HTMLElement | Element

      CSS selector string, p5.Element, or HTML element to search within

    Returns Element

    p5.Element containing node found

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.select

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/dom/dom.d.ts:273

selectAll

  • selectAll(selectors, container?): Element[]

  • Searches the page for elements that match the given CSS selector string (can be an ID a class, tag name or a combination) and returns them as p5.Elements in an array. The DOM node itself can be accessed with .elt. Returns an empty array if none found. You can also specify a container to search within.

    Parameters

    • selectors: string

      CSS selector string of elements to search for

    • Optional container: string | HTMLElement | Element

      CSS selector string, p5.Element , or HTML element to search within

    Returns Element[]

    Array of p5.Elements containing nodes found

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.selectAll

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/dom/dom.d.ts:290

set

  • set(x, y, c): void

  • Changes the color of any pixel, or writes an image directly to the display window. The x and y parameters specify the pixel to change and the c parameter specifies the color value. This can be a p5.Color object, or [R, G, B, A] pixel array. It can also be a single grayscale value. When setting an image, the x and y parameters define the coordinates for the upper-left corner of the image, regardless of the current imageMode(). After using set(), you must call updatePixels() for your changes to appear. This should be called once all pixels have been set, and must be called before calling .get() or drawing the image.

    Setting the color of a single pixel with set(x, y) is easy, but not as fast as putting the data directly into pixels[]. Setting the pixels[] values directly may be complicated when working with a retina display, but will perform better when lots of pixels need to be set directly on every loop. See the reference for pixels[] for more information.

    Parameters

    • x: number

      x-coordinate of the pixel

    • y: number

      y-coordinate of the pixel

    • c: number | object | number[]

      insert a grayscale value | a pixel array | a p5.Color object | a p5.Image to copy

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.set

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/image/pixels.d.ts:327

setAttributes

  • setAttributes(key, value): void

  • Set attributes for the WebGL Drawing context. This is a way of adjusting how the WebGL renderer works to fine-tune the display and performance. Note that this will reinitialize the drawing context if called after the WebGL canvas is made.

    If an object is passed as the parameter, all attributes not declared in the object will be set to defaults.

    The available attributes are:

    alpha - indicates if the canvas contains an alpha buffer default is true

    depth - indicates whether the drawing buffer has a depth buffer of at least 16 bits - default is true

    stencil - indicates whether the drawing buffer has a stencil buffer of at least 8 bits

    antialias - indicates whether or not to perform anti-aliasing default is false (true in Safari)

    premultipliedAlpha - indicates that the page compositor will assume the drawing buffer contains colors with pre-multiplied alpha default is true

    preserveDrawingBuffer - if true the buffers will not be cleared and and will preserve their values until cleared or overwritten by author (note that p5 clears automatically on draw loop) default is true

    perPixelLighting - if true, per-pixel lighting will be used in the lighting shader otherwise per-vertex lighting is used. default is true.

    version - either 1 or 2, to specify which WebGL version to ask for. By default, WebGL 2 will be requested. If WebGL2 is not available, it will fall back to WebGL 1. You can check what version is used with by looking at the global webglVersion property.

    Parameters

    • key: string

      Name of attribute

    • value: boolean

      New value of named attribute

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.setAttributes

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/p5.RendererGL.d.ts:55
  • setAttributes(obj): void

  • Set attributes for the WebGL Drawing context. This is a way of adjusting how the WebGL renderer works to fine-tune the display and performance. Note that this will reinitialize the drawing context if called after the WebGL canvas is made.

    If an object is passed as the parameter, all attributes not declared in the object will be set to defaults.

    The available attributes are:

    alpha - indicates if the canvas contains an alpha buffer default is true

    depth - indicates whether the drawing buffer has a depth buffer of at least 16 bits - default is true

    stencil - indicates whether the drawing buffer has a stencil buffer of at least 8 bits

    antialias - indicates whether or not to perform anti-aliasing default is false (true in Safari)

    premultipliedAlpha - indicates that the page compositor will assume the drawing buffer contains colors with pre-multiplied alpha default is true

    preserveDrawingBuffer - if true the buffers will not be cleared and and will preserve their values until cleared or overwritten by author (note that p5 clears automatically on draw loop) default is true

    perPixelLighting - if true, per-pixel lighting will be used in the lighting shader otherwise per-vertex lighting is used. default is true.

    version - either 1 or 2, to specify which WebGL version to ask for. By default, WebGL 2 will be requested. If WebGL2 is not available, it will fall back to WebGL 1. You can check what version is used with by looking at the global webglVersion property.

    Parameters

    • obj: object

      object with key-value pairs

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.setAttributes

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/p5.RendererGL.d.ts:104

setup

  • setup(): void

  • The setup() function is called once when the program starts. It's used to define initial environment properties such as screen size and background color and to load media such as images and fonts as the program starts. There can only be one setup() function for each program and it shouldn't be called again after its initial execution. Note: Variables declared within setup() are not accessible within other functions, including draw().

    Returns void

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/index.d.ts:116

shader

  • shader(s): p5

  • Sets the p5.Shader object to be used to render subsequent shapes. Custom shaders can be created using the createShader() and loadShader() functions.

    Use resetShader() to restore the default shaders.

    Note, shaders can only be used in WEBGL mode.

    Parameters

    • s: Shader

      the p5.Shader object to use for rendering shapes.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.shader

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/material.d.ts:58

shearX

  • shearX(angle): p5

  • Shears a shape around the x-axis by the amount specified by the angle parameter. Angles should be specified in the current angleMode. Objects are always sheared around their relative position to the origin and positive numbers shear objects in a clockwise direction. Transformations apply to everything that happens after and subsequent calls to the function accumulates the effect. For example, calling shearX(PI/2) and then shearX(PI/2) is the same as shearX(PI). If shearX() is called within the draw(), the transformation is reset when the loop begins again.

    Technically, shearX() multiplies the current transformation matrix by a rotation matrix. This function can be further controlled by the push() and pop() functions.

    Parameters

    • angle: number

      angle of shear specified in radians or degrees, depending on current angleMode

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.shearX

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:265

shearY

  • shearY(angle): p5

  • Shears a shape around the y-axis the amount specified by the angle parameter. Angles should be specified in the current angleMode. Objects are always sheared around their relative position to the origin and positive numbers shear objects in a clockwise direction. Transformations apply to everything that happens after and subsequent calls to the function accumulates the effect. For example, calling shearY(PI/2) and then shearY(PI/2) is the same as shearY(PI). If shearY() is called within the draw(), the transformation is reset when the loop begins again.

    Technically, shearY() multiplies the current transformation matrix by a rotation matrix. This function can be further controlled by the push() and pop() functions.

    Parameters

    • angle: number

      angle of shear specified in radians or degrees, depending on current angleMode

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.shearY

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/transform.d.ts:290

smooth

  • smooth(): p5

  • Draws all geometry with smooth (anti-aliased) edges. smooth() will also improve image quality of resized images. smooth() is active by default in 2D mode. It's necessary to call noSmooth() to disable smoothing of geometry, images, and fonts.

    In WebGL mode, noSmooth() is active by default. It's necessary to call smooth() to draw smooth (antialiased) edges.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.smooth

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/attributes.d.ts:95

sort

  • sort(list, count?): any[]

  • Sorts an array of numbers from smallest to largest, or puts an array of words in alphabetical order. The original array is not modified; a re-ordered array is returned. The count parameter states the number of elements to sort. For example, if there are 12 elements in an array and count is set to 5, only the first 5 elements in the array will be sorted.

    Parameters

    • list: any[]

      Array to sort

    • Optional count: number

      number of elements to sort, starting from 0

    Returns any[]

    the sorted list

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.sort

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/utilities/array_functions.d.ts:118

specularColor

  • specularColor(v1, v2, v3): p5

  • Sets the color of the specular highlight of a non-ambient light (i.e. all lights except ambientLight()). specularColor() affects only the lights which are created after it in the code.

    This function is used in combination with specularMaterial(). If a geometry does not use specularMaterial(), this function will have no effect.

    The default color is white (255, 255, 255), which is used if specularColor() is not explicitly called.

    Note: specularColor is equivalent to the Processing function lightSpecular.

    Parameters

    • v1: number

      red or hue value relative to the current color range

    • v2: number

      green or saturation value relative to the current color range

    • v3: number

      blue or brightness value relative to the current color range

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.specularColor

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/light.d.ts:128
  • specularColor(gray): p5

  • Sets the color of the specular highlight of a non-ambient light (i.e. all lights except ambientLight()). specularColor() affects only the lights which are created after it in the code.

    This function is used in combination with specularMaterial(). If a geometry does not use specularMaterial(), this function will have no effect.

    The default color is white (255, 255, 255), which is used if specularColor() is not explicitly called.

    Note: specularColor is equivalent to the Processing function lightSpecular.

    Parameters

    • gray: number

      number specifying value between white and black

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.specularColor

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/light.d.ts:151
  • specularColor(value): p5

  • Sets the color of the specular highlight of a non-ambient light (i.e. all lights except ambientLight()). specularColor() affects only the lights which are created after it in the code.

    This function is used in combination with specularMaterial(). If a geometry does not use specularMaterial(), this function will have no effect.

    The default color is white (255, 255, 255), which is used if specularColor() is not explicitly called.

    Note: specularColor is equivalent to the Processing function lightSpecular.

    Parameters

    • value: string

      color as a CSS string

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.specularColor

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/light.d.ts:173
  • specularColor(values): p5

  • Sets the color of the specular highlight of a non-ambient light (i.e. all lights except ambientLight()). specularColor() affects only the lights which are created after it in the code.

    This function is used in combination with specularMaterial(). If a geometry does not use specularMaterial(), this function will have no effect.

    The default color is white (255, 255, 255), which is used if specularColor() is not explicitly called.

    Note: specularColor is equivalent to the Processing function lightSpecular.

    Parameters

    • values: number[]

      color as an array containing the red, green, and blue components

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.specularColor

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/light.d.ts:196
  • specularColor(color): p5

  • Sets the color of the specular highlight of a non-ambient light (i.e. all lights except ambientLight()). specularColor() affects only the lights which are created after it in the code.

    This function is used in combination with specularMaterial(). If a geometry does not use specularMaterial(), this function will have no effect.

    The default color is white (255, 255, 255), which is used if specularColor() is not explicitly called.

    Note: specularColor is equivalent to the Processing function lightSpecular.

    Parameters

    • color: p5.Color

      color as a p5.Color

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.specularColor

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/light.d.ts:218

specularMaterial

  • specularMaterial(gray, alpha?): p5

  • Sets the specular color of the material. A specular material is reflective (shiny). The shininess can be controlled by the shininess() function.

    Like ambientMaterial(), the specularMaterial() color is the color the object will reflect under ambientLight(). However unlike ambientMaterial(), for all other types of lights (directionalLight(), pointLight(), spotLight()), a specular material will reflect the color of the light source. This is what gives it its "shiny" appearance.

    You can view more materials in this example.

    Parameters

    • gray: number

      number specifying value between white and black.

    • Optional alpha: number

      alpha value relative to current color range (default is 0-255)

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.specularMaterial

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/material.d.ts:298
  • specularMaterial(v1, v2, v3, alpha?): p5

  • Sets the specular color of the material. A specular material is reflective (shiny). The shininess can be controlled by the shininess() function.

    Like ambientMaterial(), the specularMaterial() color is the color the object will reflect under ambientLight(). However unlike ambientMaterial(), for all other types of lights (directionalLight(), pointLight(), spotLight()), a specular material will reflect the color of the light source. This is what gives it its "shiny" appearance.

    You can view more materials in this example.

    Parameters

    • v1: number

      red or hue value relative to the current color range

    • v2: number

      green or saturation value relative to the current color range

    • v3: number

      blue or brightness value relative to the current color range

    • Optional alpha: number

      alpha value relative to current color range (default is 0-255)

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.specularMaterial

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/material.d.ts:325
  • specularMaterial(color): p5

  • Sets the specular color of the material. A specular material is reflective (shiny). The shininess can be controlled by the shininess() function.

    Like ambientMaterial(), the specularMaterial() color is the color the object will reflect under ambientLight(). However unlike ambientMaterial(), for all other types of lights (directionalLight(), pointLight(), spotLight()), a specular material will reflect the color of the light source. This is what gives it its "shiny" appearance.

    You can view more materials in this example.

    Parameters

    • color: string | number[] | p5.Color

      color as a p5.Color, as an array, or as a CSS string

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.specularMaterial

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/material.d.ts:346

sphere

  • sphere(radius?, detailX?, detailY?): p5

  • Draw a sphere with given radius. DetailX and detailY determines the number of subdivisions in the x-dimension and the y-dimension of a sphere. More subdivisions make the sphere seem smoother. The recommended maximum values are both 24. Using a value greater than 24 may cause a warning or slow down the browser.

    Parameters

    • Optional radius: number

      radius of circle

    • Optional detailX: number

      optional number of subdivisions in x-dimension

    • Optional detailY: number

      optional number of subdivisions in y-dimension

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.sphere

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/3d_primitives.d.ts:47

splice

  • splice(list, value, position): any[]

  • Inserts a value or an array of values into an existing array. The first parameter specifies the initial array to be modified, and the second parameter defines the data to be inserted. The third parameter is an index value which specifies the array position from which to insert data. (Remember that array index numbering starts at zero, so the first position is 0, the second position is 1, and so on.)

    Parameters

    • list: any[]

      Array to splice into

    • value: any

      value to be spliced in

    • position: number

      in the array from which to insert data

    Returns any[]

    the list

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.splice

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/utilities/array_functions.d.ts:136

split

  • split(value, delim): string[]

  • The split() function maps to String.split(), it breaks a String into pieces using a character or string as the delimiter. The delim parameter specifies the character or characters that mark the boundaries between each piece. A String[] array is returned that contains each of the pieces. The splitTokens() function works in a similar fashion, except that it splits using a range of characters instead of a specific character or sequence.

    Parameters

    • value: string

      the String to be split

    • delim: string

      the String used to separate the data

    Returns string[]

    Array of Strings

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.split

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/utilities/string_functions.d.ts:281

splitTokens

  • splitTokens(value, delim?): string[]

  • The splitTokens() function splits a String at one or many character delimiters or "tokens." The delim parameter specifies the character or characters to be used as a boundary. If no delim characters are specified, any whitespace character is used to split. Whitespace characters include tab (\t), line feed (\n), carriage return (\r), form feed (\f), and space.

    Parameters

    • value: string

      the String to be split

    • Optional delim: string

      list of individual Strings that will be used as separators

    Returns string[]

    Array of Strings

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.splitTokens

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/utilities/string_functions.d.ts:297

spotLight

  • spotLight(v1, v2, v3, x, y, z, rx, ry, rz, angle?, concentration?): p5

  • Creates a spot light with the given color, position, light direction, angle, and concentration. Like a pointLight(), a spotLight() emits light from a specific point (position). It has a different effect when it is positioned farther vs. nearer an object.

    However, unlike a pointLight(), the light is emitted in one direction along a conical shape. The shape of the cone can be controlled using the angle and concentration parameters.

    The angle parameter is used to determine the radius of the cone. And the concentration parameter is used to focus the light towards the center of the cone. Both parameters are optional, however if you want to specify concentration, you must also specify angle. The minimum concentration value is 1.

    A maximum of 5 spot lights can be active at once.

    Note: lights need to be called (whether directly or indirectly) within draw() to remain persistent in a looping program. Placing them in setup() will cause them to only have an effect the first time through the loop.

    Parameters

    • v1: number

      red or hue value relative to the current color range

    • v2: number

      green or saturation value relative to the current color range

    • v3: number

      blue or brightness value relative to the current color range

    • x: number

      x component of position

    • y: number

      y component of position

    • z: number

      z component of position

    • rx: number

      x component of light direction (inclusive range of -1 to 1)

    • ry: number

      y component of light direction (inclusive range of -1 to 1)

    • rz: number

      z component of light direction (inclusive range of -1 to 1)

    • Optional angle: number

      angle of cone. Defaults to PI/3

    • Optional concentration: number

      concentration of cone. Defaults to 100

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.spotLight

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/light.d.ts:545
  • spotLight(color, position, direction, angle?, concentration?): void

  • Creates a spot light with the given color, position, light direction, angle, and concentration. Like a pointLight(), a spotLight() emits light from a specific point (position). It has a different effect when it is positioned farther vs. nearer an object.

    However, unlike a pointLight(), the light is emitted in one direction along a conical shape. The shape of the cone can be controlled using the angle and concentration parameters.

    The angle parameter is used to determine the radius of the cone. And the concentration parameter is used to focus the light towards the center of the cone. Both parameters are optional, however if you want to specify concentration, you must also specify angle. The minimum concentration value is 1.

    A maximum of 5 spot lights can be active at once.

    Note: lights need to be called (whether directly or indirectly) within draw() to remain persistent in a looping program. Placing them in setup() will cause them to only have an effect the first time through the loop.

    Parameters

    • color: string | number[] | p5.Color

      color as a p5.Color, as an array, or as a CSS string

    • position: Vector

      position of light as a p5.Vector

    • direction: Vector

      direction of light as a p5.Vector

    • Optional angle: number

      angle of cone. Defaults to PI/3

    • Optional concentration: number

      concentration of cone. Defaults to 100

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.spotLight

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/webgl/light.d.ts:595

  • Creates a spot light with the given color, position, light direction, angle, and concentration. Like a pointLight(), a spotLight() emits light from a specific point (position). It has a different effect when it is positioned farther vs. nearer an object.

    However, unlike a pointLight(), the light is emitted in one direction along a conical shape. The shape of the cone can be controlled using the angle and concentration parameters.

    The angle parameter is used to determine the radius of the cone. And the concentration parameter is used to focus the light towards the center of the cone. sq

  • sq(n): number

  • Squares a number (multiplies a number by itself). The result is always a positive number, as multiplying two negative numbers always yields a positive result. For example, -1 * -1 = 1.

    Parameters

    • n: number

      number to square

    Returns number

    squared number

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.sq

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/calculation.d.ts:239

sqrt

  • sqrt(n): number

  • Calculates the square root of a number. The square root of a number is always positive, even though there may be a valid negative root. The square root s of number a is such that s*s = a. It is the opposite of squaring. Maps to Math.sqrt().

    Parameters

    • n: number

      non-negative number to square root

    Returns number

    square root of number

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.sqrt

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/calculation.d.ts:250

square

  • square(x, y, s, tl?, tr?, br?, bl?): p5

  • Draws a square to the canvas. A square is a four-sided polygon with every angle at ninety degrees and equal side lengths. By default, the first two parameters set the location of the square's upper-left corner. The third parameter sets its side size. The way these parameters are interpreted may be changed with the rectMode() function. The version of square() with four parameters creates a rounded square. The fourth parameter is used as the radius value for all four corners.

    The version of square() with seven parameters also creates a rounded square. When using seven parameters, the latter four set the radius of the arc at each corner separately. The radii start with the top-left corner and move clockwise around the square. If any of these parameters are omitted, they are set to the value of the last specified corner radius.

    Parameters

    • x: number

      x-coordinate of the square.

    • y: number

      y-coordinate of the square.

    • s: number

      side size of the square.

    • Optional tl: number

      optional radius of top-left corner.

    • Optional tr: number

      optional radius of top-right corner.

    • Optional br: number

      optional radius of bottom-right corner.

    • Optional bl: number

      optional radius of bottom-left corner.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.square

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/2d_primitives.d.ts:376

storeItem

  • storeItem(key, value): void

  • Stores a value in local storage under the key name. Local storage is saved in the browser and persists between browsing sessions and page reloads. The key can be the name of the variable but doesn't have to be. To retrieve stored items see getItem. Sensitive data such as passwords or personal information should not be stored in local storage.

    Parameters

    • key: string
    • value: string | number | boolean | object | p5.Color | Vector

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.storeItem

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/data/local_storage.d.ts:17

str

  • str(n): string

  • Converts a boolean, string or number to its string representation. When an array of values is passed in, then an array of strings of the same length is returned.

    Parameters

    • n: string | number | boolean | any[]

      value to parse

    Returns string

    string representation of value

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.str

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/utilities/conversion.d.ts:52

stroke

  • stroke(v1, v2, v3, alpha?): p5

  • Sets the color used to draw lines and borders around shapes. Calling stroke(255, 165, 0) or stroke('orange') means all shapes drawn after the stroke() command will be filled with the color orange. The way these parameters are interpreted may be changed with the colorMode() function. The version of stroke() with one parameter interprets the value one of three ways. If the parameter is a number, it's interpreted as a grayscale value. If the parameter is a string, it's interpreted as a CSS color string. A p5.Color object can also be provided to set the stroke color.

    The version of stroke() with two parameters interprets the first one as a grayscale value. The second parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    The version of stroke() with three parameters interprets them as RGB, HSB, or HSL colors, depending on the current colorMode().

    The version of stroke() with four parameters interprets them as RGBA, HSBA, or HSLA colors, depending on the current colorMode(). The last parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    Parameters

    • v1: number

      red value if color mode is RGB or hue value if color mode is HSB.

    • v2: number

      green value if color mode is RGB or saturation value if color mode is HSB.

    • v3: number

      blue value if color mode is RGB or brightness value if color mode is HSB.

    • Optional alpha: number

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.stroke

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/color/setting.d.ts:496
  • stroke(value): p5

  • Sets the color used to draw lines and borders around shapes. Calling stroke(255, 165, 0) or stroke('orange') means all shapes drawn after the stroke() command will be filled with the color orange. The way these parameters are interpreted may be changed with the colorMode() function. The version of stroke() with one parameter interprets the value one of three ways. If the parameter is a number, it's interpreted as a grayscale value. If the parameter is a string, it's interpreted as a CSS color string. A p5.Color object can also be provided to set the stroke color.

    The version of stroke() with two parameters interprets the first one as a grayscale value. The second parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    The version of stroke() with three parameters interprets them as RGB, HSB, or HSL colors, depending on the current colorMode().

    The version of stroke() with four parameters interprets them as RGBA, HSBA, or HSLA colors, depending on the current colorMode(). The last parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    Parameters

    • value: string

      a color string.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.stroke

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/color/setting.d.ts:528
  • stroke(gray, alpha?): p5

  • Sets the color used to draw lines and borders around shapes. Calling stroke(255, 165, 0) or stroke('orange') means all shapes drawn after the stroke() command will be filled with the color orange. The way these parameters are interpreted may be changed with the colorMode() function. The version of stroke() with one parameter interprets the value one of three ways. If the parameter is a number, it's interpreted as a grayscale value. If the parameter is a string, it's interpreted as a CSS color string. A p5.Color object can also be provided to set the stroke color.

    The version of stroke() with two parameters interprets the first one as a grayscale value. The second parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    The version of stroke() with three parameters interprets them as RGB, HSB, or HSL colors, depending on the current colorMode().

    The version of stroke() with four parameters interprets them as RGBA, HSBA, or HSLA colors, depending on the current colorMode(). The last parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    Parameters

    • gray: number

      a grayscale value.

    • Optional alpha: number

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.stroke

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/color/setting.d.ts:560
  • stroke(values): p5

  • Sets the color used to draw lines and borders around shapes. Calling stroke(255, 165, 0) or stroke('orange') means all shapes drawn after the stroke() command will be filled with the color orange. The way these parameters are interpreted may be changed with the colorMode() function. The version of stroke() with one parameter interprets the value one of three ways. If the parameter is a number, it's interpreted as a grayscale value. If the parameter is a string, it's interpreted as a CSS color string. A p5.Color object can also be provided to set the stroke color.

    The version of stroke() with two parameters interprets the first one as a grayscale value. The second parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    The version of stroke() with three parameters interprets them as RGB, HSB, or HSL colors, depending on the current colorMode().

    The version of stroke() with four parameters interprets them as RGBA, HSBA, or HSLA colors, depending on the current colorMode(). The last parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    Parameters

    • values: number[]

      an array containing the red, green, blue, and alpha components of the color.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.stroke

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/color/setting.d.ts:593
  • stroke(color): p5

  • Sets the color used to draw lines and borders around shapes. Calling stroke(255, 165, 0) or stroke('orange') means all shapes drawn after the stroke() command will be filled with the color orange. The way these parameters are interpreted may be changed with the colorMode() function. The version of stroke() with one parameter interprets the value one of three ways. If the parameter is a number, it's interpreted as a grayscale value. If the parameter is a string, it's interpreted as a CSS color string. A p5.Color object can also be provided to set the stroke color.

    The version of stroke() with two parameters interprets the first one as a grayscale value. The second parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    The version of stroke() with three parameters interprets them as RGB, HSB, or HSL colors, depending on the current colorMode().

    The version of stroke() with four parameters interprets them as RGBA, HSBA, or HSLA colors, depending on the current colorMode(). The last parameter sets the alpha (transparency) value.

    Parameters

    • color: p5.Color

      the stroke color.

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.stroke

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/color/setting.d.ts:625

strokeCap

  • strokeCap(cap): p5

  • Sets the style for rendering line endings. These ends are either rounded (ROUND), squared (SQUARE), or extended (PROJECT). The default cap is ROUND. The argument passed to strokeCap() must be written in ALL CAPS because the constants ROUND, SQUARE, and PROJECT are defined this way. JavaScript is a case-sensitive language.

    Parameters

    • cap: STROKE_CAP

      either ROUND, SQUARE, or PROJECT

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.strokeCap

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/attributes.d.ts:108

strokeJoin

  • strokeJoin(join): p5

  • Sets the style of the joints which connect line segments. These joints are either mitered (MITER), beveled (BEVEL), or rounded (ROUND). The default joint is MITER in 2D mode and ROUND in WebGL mode. The argument passed to strokeJoin() must be written in ALL CAPS because the constants MITER, BEVEL, and ROUND are defined this way. JavaScript is a case-sensitive language.

    Parameters

    • join: STROKE_JOIN

      either MITER, BEVEL, or ROUND

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.strokeJoin

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/attributes.d.ts:122

strokeWeight

  • strokeWeight(weight): p5

  • Sets the width of the stroke used for lines, points, and the border around shapes. All widths are set in units of pixels. Note that strokeWeight() is affected by any transformation or scaling that has been applied previously.

    Parameters

    • weight: number

      the weight of the stroke (in pixels).

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.strokeWeight

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/core/shape/attributes.d.ts:134

subset

  • subset(list, start, count?): any[]

  • Extracts an array of elements from an existing array. The list parameter defines the array from which the elements will be copied, and the start and count parameters specify which elements to extract. If no count is given, elements will be extracted from the start to the end of the array. When specifying the start, remember that the first array element is 0. This function does not change the source array.

    Parameters

    • list: any[]

      Array to extract from

    • start: number

      position to begin

    • Optional count: number

      number of values to extract

    Returns any[]

    Array of extracted elements

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.subset

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/utilities/array_functions.d.ts:153

tan

  • tan(angle): number

  • Calculates the tangent of an angle. This function takes into account the current angleMode. Values are returned in the range of all real numbers.

    Parameters

    • angle: number

      the angle

    Returns number

    the tangent of the angle

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.tan

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/math/trigonometry.d.ts:87

text

  • text(str, x, y, x2?, y2?): p5

  • Draws text to the screen. Displays the information specified in the first parameter on the screen in the position specified by the additional parameters. A default font will be used unless a font is set with the textFont() function and a default size will be used unless a font is set with textSize(). Change the color of the text with the fill() function. Change the outline of the text with the stroke() and strokeWeight() functions. The text displays in relation to the textAlign() function, which gives the option to draw to the left, right, and center of the coordinates.

    The x2 and y2 parameters define a rectangular area to display within and may only be used with string data. When these parameters are specified, they are interpreted based on the current rectMode() setting. Text that does not fit completely within the rectangle specified will not be drawn to the screen. If x2 and y2 are not specified, the baseline alignment is the default, which means that the text will be drawn upwards from x and y.

    WEBGL: Only opentype/truetype fonts are supported. You must load a font using the loadFont() method (see the example above). stroke() currently has no effect in webgl mode. Learn more about working with text in webgl mode on the wiki.

    Parameters

    • str: string | number | boolean | object | any[]

      the alphanumeric symbols to be displayed

    • x: number

      x-coordinate of text

    • y: number

      y-coordinate of text

    • Optional x2: number

      by default, the width of the text box, see rectMode() for more info

    • Optional y2: number

      by default, the height of the text box, see rectMode() for more info

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.text

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/typography/loading_displaying.d.ts:66

textAlign

  • textAlign(horizAlign, vertAlign?): p5

  • Sets the current alignment for drawing text. Accepts two arguments: horizAlign (LEFT, CENTER, or RIGHT) and vertAlign (TOP, BOTTOM, CENTER, or BASELINE). The horizAlign parameter is in reference to the x value of the text() function, while the vertAlign parameter is in reference to the y value.

    So if you write textAlign(LEFT), you are aligning the left edge of your text to the x value you give in text(). If you write textAlign(RIGHT, TOP), you are aligning the right edge of your text to the x value and the top edge of the text to the y value.

    Parameters

    • horizAlign: HORIZ_ALIGN

      horizontal alignment, either LEFT, CENTER, or RIGHT

    • Optional vertAlign: VERT_ALIGN

      vertical alignment, either TOP, BOTTOM, CENTER, or BASELINE

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textAlign

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/typography/attributes.d.ts:27
  • textAlign(): object

  • Sets the current alignment for drawing text. Accepts two arguments: horizAlign (LEFT, CENTER, or RIGHT) and vertAlign (TOP, BOTTOM, CENTER, or BASELINE). The horizAlign parameter is in reference to the x value of the text() function, while the vertAlign parameter is in reference to the y value.

    So if you write textAlign(LEFT), you are aligning the left edge of your text to the x value you give in text(). If you write textAlign(RIGHT, TOP), you are aligning the right edge of your text to the x value and the top edge of the text to the y value.

    Returns object

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textAlign

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/typography/attributes.d.ts:44

textAscent

  • textAscent(): number

  • Returns the ascent of the current font at its current size. The ascent represents the distance, in pixels, of the tallest character above the baseline.

    Returns number

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textAscent

textDescent

  • textDescent(): number

  • Returns the descent of the current font at its current size. The descent represents the distance, in pixels, of the character with the longest descender below the baseline.

    Returns number

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textDescent

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/typography/attributes.d.ts:123

textFont

  • textFont(): object

  • Sets the current font that will be drawn with the text() function. If textFont() is called without any argument, it will return the current font if one has been set already. If not, it will return the name of the default font as a string. If textFont() is called with a font to use, it will return the p5 object. WEBGL: Only fonts loaded via loadFont() are supported.

    Returns object

    the current font / p5 Object

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textFont

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/typography/loading_displaying.d.ts:79
  • textFont(font, size?): p5

  • Sets the current font that will be drawn with the text() function. If textFont() is called without any argument, it will return the current font if one has been set already. If not, it will return the name of the default font as a string. If textFont() is called with a font to use, it will return the p5 object. WEBGL: Only fonts loaded via loadFont() are supported.

    Parameters

    • font: string | object

      a font loaded via loadFont(), or a String representing a web safe font (a font that is generally available across all systems)

    • Optional size: number

      the font size to use

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textFont

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/typography/loading_displaying.d.ts:96

textLeading

  • textLeading(leading): p5

  • Sets/gets the spacing, in pixels, between lines of text. This setting will be used in all subsequent calls to the text() function.

    Parameters

    • leading: number

      the size in pixels for spacing between lines

    Returns p5

    Chainable

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textLeading

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/typography/attributes.d.ts:54

  • Sets/gets the spacing, in pixels, between lines of text. This setting will be used in all subsequent calls to the text() function.

    Returns number

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textLeading

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/typography/attributes.d.ts:61

textOutput

  • textOutput(display?): void

  • textOutput() creates a screenreader accessible output that describes the shapes present on the canvas. The general description of the canvas includes canvas size, canvas color, and number of elements in the canvas (example: 'Your output is a, 400 by 400 pixels, lavender blue canvas containing the following 4 shapes:'). This description is followed by a list of shapes where the color, position, and area of each shape are described (example: "orange ellipse at top left covering 1% of the canvas"). Each element can be selected to get more details. A table of elements is also provided. In this table, shape, color, location, coordinates and area are described (example: "orange ellipse location=top left area=2"). textOutput() and textOutput(FALLBACK) make the output available in a sub DOM inside the canvas element which is accessible to screen readers. textOutput(LABEL) creates an additional div with the output adjacent to the canvas, this is useful for non-screen reader users that might want to display the output outside of the canvas' sub DOM as they code. However, using LABEL will create unnecessary redundancy for screen reader users. We recommend using LABEL only as part of the development process of a sketch and removing it before publishing or sharing with screen reader users.

    Parameters

    • Optional display: TEXT_DISPLAY

      either FALLBACK or LABEL

    Returns void

    Inherited from p5InstanceExtensions.textOutput

    • Defined in node_modules/@types/p5/src/accessibility/outputs.d.ts:38

textSize

  • textSize(theSize): p5

  • Sets/gets the current font size. This size will be used in all subsequent calls to the text() function. Font size is measured in pixels.

    Parameters

      the size of the letters in units of pixels

    Returns p5

    Parameters

      styling for text, either NORMAL, ITALIC, BOLD or BOLDITALIC
